features.description: Users can initialize new Rojo projects with built-in templates for place, plugin, and model types
steps: Run 'rojo init' command with optional --kind flag
Choose project type: place, plugin, or model
Rojo creates project structure with default.project.json and template files
Optional: Rojo initializes a Git repository if git is available
acceptance_criteria: Users can create new place projects
Users can create new plugin projects
Users can create new model projects
Project files are created with correct structure
Git repository is initialized when available

features.description: Users can run a development server that syncs code changes from filesystem to Roblox Studio in real-time
steps: Run 'rojo serve' command in project directory
Server starts listening on configurable IP address and port (default 127.0.0.1:34872)
Server displays connection information in terminal
Roblox Studio plugin connects to server to receive live updates
File system changes are automatically pushed to connected clients
acceptance_criteria: Server starts and listens on specified address and port
Server displays startup messages with connection details
File changes trigger instant updates to Studio
Plugin can connect and receive live updates
Custom ports can be configured in project

features.description: Users can compile their Rojo projects into Roblox binary or XML model and place files
steps: Run 'rojo build' command with --output flag
Specify output format: .rbxl (binary place), .rbxlx (XML place), .rbxm (binary model), or .rbxmx (XML model)
Rojo compiles project into specified output file
Optional: Use --watch flag for automatic rebuilds on file changes
Built file is ready for deployment or further editing in Studio
acceptance_criteria: Users can build binary place files (.rbxl)
Users can build XML place files (.rbxlx)
Users can build binary model files (.rbxm)
Users can build XML model files (.rbxmx)
Watch mode automatically rebuilds on changes
Built files are valid Roblox files

features.description: Users can build Rojo projects directly to their Roblox Studio plugins folder
steps: Run 'rojo build' command with --plugin flag
Specify relative path to plugin file (e.g., MyPlugin.rbxm)
Rojo detects Roblox Studio installation location
Built file is automatically placed in Roblox Studio plugins folder
Plugin is immediately available in Studio
acceptance_criteria: Users can build directly to plugins folder
Plugin files are placed in correct location
Only .rbxm and .rbxmx formats are supported for plugins

features.description: Users can upload built projects directly to Roblox.com without using Studio's GUI
steps: Run 'rojo upload' command with --asset_id flag
Provide authentication via --cookie or allow Rojo to find it automatically
Optional: Use Open Cloud API with --api_key and --universe_id flags
Rojo builds the project and uploads to specified asset ID
Upload status is displayed in terminal
acceptance_criteria: Users can upload using legacy authentication cookie
Users can upload using Open Cloud API
Authentication cookie is detected automatically from system
Upload process provides clear status feedback
Asset ID is required to specify upload target

features.description: Users can convert existing Roblox model or place files back into Rojo project structure
steps: Run 'rojo syncback' command with --input flag pointing to .rbxl, .rbxlx, .rbxm, or .rbxmx file
Provide project path to sync to
Optional: Use --dry-run to preview changes without writing
Optional: Use --list to see all files that will be added/removed
Rojo converts Roblox instances to filesystem representation
Project files are written to disk
acceptance_criteria: Users can syncback from binary place files
Users can syncback from XML place files
Users can syncback from binary model files
Users can syncback from XML model files
Dry run mode shows changes without writing

features.description: Rojo automatically converts various file types on filesystem into appropriate Roblox instances
steps: User creates files in Rojo project directory with specific extensions
Rojo scans directory structure and identifies file types
Appropriate middleware processes each file type
Files are converted to Roblox instances automatically
acceptance_criteria: Lua files (.lua) are converted to Script instances
JSON files are converted appropriately based on content
YAML files (.yaml, .yml) are converted to data instances
CSV files are converted to data tables
TOML files are converted to data instances

features.description: Rojo handles Lua script files with support for server scripts, local scripts, and module scripts
steps: User creates .lua files in project directory
Rojo detects script type based on file path conventions or metadata
Scripts are converted to appropriate Instance class (Script, LocalScript, ModuleScript)
Script source code is stored as source property
acceptance_criteria: Server scripts are created as Script instances
Client scripts are created as LocalScript instances
Module scripts are created as ModuleScript instances
Legacy script naming conventions are supported

features.description: Users can define instance properties and metadata using .meta.json files alongside source files
steps: User creates .meta.json file in project directory
File contains instance properties in JSON format
Metadata file is linked to corresponding source file or directory
Properties from metadata override defaults
acceptance_criteria: Users can define custom properties via metadata
Metadata files are properly linked to instances

features.description: Users can configure Rojo projects via default.project.json or default.project.jsonc files
steps: User creates or edits default.project.json in project root
Define project name, tree structure, and configuration options
Set serve_port for custom development server port
Define serve_place_ids for place compatibility checking
Rojo loads configuration when project is accessed
acceptance_criteria: Tree structure can be defined in project file
Custom serve ports can be set
Place ID whitelists can be configured
Place ID blacklists can be configured

features.description: Users can generate sourcemap JSON files that map Roblox instances back to filesystem locations
steps: Run 'rojo sourcemap' command with optional --output flag
Rojo generates JSON tree mapping instances to file paths
Sourcemap shows hierarchy of all instances and their source files
Output can be written to file or printed to stdout
Optional: Use --absolute flag for absolute file paths
acceptance_criteria: Sourcemap is generated as valid JSON
Sourcemap includes file paths for instances
Relative and absolute path options work
Watch mode tracks changes to sourcemap

features.description: Users can automatically format project.json files using standard JSON formatting rules
steps: Run 'rojo fmt-project' command in project directory
Rojo loads project file
Rojo reformats JSON with standard indentation and spacing
Formatted project is written back to file
acceptance_criteria: Project files are reformatted with consistent style
Formatted file is written back in place

features.description: Users can generate documentation from Rojo projects to understand project structure
steps: Run 'rojo doc' command
Rojo scans project and generates documentation
Documentation is displayed in terminal or saved to file
acceptance_criteria: Documentation is generated from project structure
Output format is clear and readable

features.description: Users can access a web-based dashboard when running 'rojo serve' to monitor sync status and view project structure
steps: Run 'rojo serve' command
Open browser to http://localhost:34872
Dashboard displays project structure and sync information
Real-time updates show file changes and instance modifications
acceptance_criteria: Web UI is accessible via HTTP server

features.description: Rojo server and clients communicate via WebSocket protocol for real-time synchronization
steps: Server establishes WebSocket endpoint
Client connects to WebSocket server
Changes are sent via SubscribeMessage protocol
Client receives added, updated, and removed instances

features.description: Rojo uses an in-memory virtual file system for efficient project processing without excessive disk I/O
steps: Rojo creates VFS when project loads
Files are read from disk into memory
File changes trigger VFS updates
Snapshot generation uses VFS instead of disk
acceptance_criteria: Memory usage is reasonable for typical projects

features.description: Rojo converts file system structures into Roblox instance snapshots that can be synced to Studio
steps: VFS scans project directory structure
Middleware processors convert files to instance snapshots
Instance tree is built from snapshots
Snapshots track metadata and properties
acceptance_criteria: Performance is acceptable for large projects

features.description: Rojo tracks changes and sends only modified instances to connected clients using a patch system
steps: System detects file changes
Changed instances are identified
Patch set is generated with removed, added, and updated instances
Only changes are sent to clients via WebSocket

features.description: Users can define complex model structures using JSON files with full instance property support
steps: User creates .json file in project directory
JSON defines instance structure with Name, ClassName, and Properties
Rojo parses JSON and creates instance hierarchy
Nested structures create parent-child relationships
acceptance_criteria: Properties are set from JSON data

features.description: Users can define data structures using YAML files for cleaner syntax alternatives to JSON
steps: User creates .yaml or .yml file in project
YAML syntax defines data structure
Rojo converts YAML to appropriate instances

features.description: Users can define tabular data using CSV files that are converted to Roblox data structures
steps: User creates .csv file in project
CSV defines tabular data with headers and rows
Rojo converts CSV to appropriate instance structure

features.description: Users can define configuration data using TOML files
steps: User creates .toml file in project
TOML syntax defines configuration structure
Rojo converts TOML to data instances

features.description: Users can embed pre-built binary Roblox model files (.rbxm) directly into projects
steps: User places .rbxm file in project directory
Rojo detects binary model file
File is embedded as instance in project
Model instances are included in sync
acceptance_criteria: Model contents are included in sync

features.description: Users can embed pre-built XML Roblox model files (.rbxmx) directly into projects
steps: User places .rbxmx file in project directory
Rojo detects XML model file
File is embedded as instance in project
Model instances are included in sync
acceptance_criteria: Model contents are included in sync

features.description: Users can include plain text files that are converted to TextLabel or StringValue instances
steps: User creates .txt file in project
Rojo detects text file
File content is converted to appropriate instance

features.description: Rojo automatically converts directory structures into Folder instances and hierarchies
steps: User creates directories in project
Rojo detects directory structure
Directories create Folder instances
Nested directories create nested folders

features.description: Rojo monitors file system for changes and automatically propagates updates to connected clients
steps: VFS watches for file changes
File modification is detected
Change processor calculates affected instances
Patches are generated and sent to clients

features.description: Rojo provides comprehensive error messages and logging for debugging issues
steps: User runs Rojo with various verbosity levels
Errors are caught and reported with helpful messages
Debug information is logged with --verbose flags
Backtrace is shown on crashes with RUST_BACKTRACE=1
acceptance_criteria: Error messages are clear and actionable

features.description: Rojo works across Windows, macOS, and Linux platforms with consistent behavior
steps: User installs Rojo on their platform
Rojo automatically detects Roblox Studio location
Path handling works correctly on all platforms
Features work consistently across OSes
acceptance_criteria: Studio detection works on all platforms

features.description: Rojo projects integrate with Git version control to enable collaborative development
steps: During init, Rojo optionally initializes a Git repository
Project files are structured for clean Git history
Users can version control their Rojo projects
Collaborative workflow is enabled through Git
acceptance_criteria: Git initialization is optional during init
Project structure works well with Git

features.description: The Rojo Studio plugin allows Studio to connect to Rojo server and receive live updates
steps: Plugin is installed in Roblox Studio
User connects plugin to Rojo server
Plugin receives real-time instance updates
Studio view is kept in sync with filesystem

features.description: Rojo includes optimizations for handling large projects efficiently
steps: Rojo uses in-memory VFS to reduce I/O
Patch-based sync minimizes data transfer
Parallel processing is used where applicable
Performance profiling is available with Tracy support
